alert.note: Alert for San Miguel (New Mexico) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Albuquerque (Northern and Central New Mexico)
info.headline: Flash Flood Warning issued July 09 at 6:21PM MDT until July 09 at 9:15PM MDT by NWS Albuquerque
info.description: The National Weather Service in Albuquerque has issued a * Flash Flood Warning for... The Gallinas River within the Hermits Peak Calf Canyon burn scar in... Northwestern San Miguel County in northeastern New Mexico... * Until 915 PM MDT. * At 621 PM MDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms producing heavy rain over the Gallinas River Basin within the Hermits Peak Calf Canyon Burn Scar. Up to 0.5 inches of rain have fallen. Additional rainfall amounts of 0.25 to 0.75 inches are possible in the warned area. Flash flooding is ongoing or expected to begin shortly. Excessive rainfall over the burn scar will impact the Gallinas Creek and Gallinas River drainage area including Porvenir Canyon, Arroyo Pecos, Agua Zarca and Vegosa Creek. This may also impact Rito Chavez and Beaver Creek. The debris flow can consist of rock, mud, vegetation and other loose materials. HAZARD...Life threatening flash flooding. Thunderstorms producing flash flooding in and around the Gallinas River within the Hermits Peak Calf Canyon Burn Scar. SOURCE...Radar. IMPACT...Life threatening flash flooding of areas in and around the Gallinas River within the Hermits Peak Calf Canyon Burn Scar. * Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... Las Vegas, El Porvenir, Montezuma, Storrie Lake State Park, Sapello, Gallinas and San Ignacio. This includes the following highways... State Road 94 near Mile Marker 1. State Road 266 between Mile Markers 1 and 6. State Road 518 between Mile Markers 1 and 12. Interstate 25 between Mile Markers 343 and 349. State Road 283 between Mile Markers 1 and 7. State Road 65 between Mile Markers 1 and 14. FLASH FLOOD...RADAR INDICATED FLASH FLOOD DAMAGE THREAT...CONSIDERABLE
info.instruction: Do not camp along streams and rivers. Remain alert when hiking in steep, narrow canyons. Know where you are relative to low spots and drainages. This is a life threatening situation. Heavy rainfall will cause extensive and severe flash flooding of creeks, streams and ditches in the Gallinas River within the Hermits Peak Calf Canyon Burn Scar. Severe debris flows can also be anticipated across roads. Roads and driveways may be washed away in places. If you encounter flood waters, climb to safety.
